article: For years scientists have been arguing about whether nature or nurture decides what people will be like. Is it nature-- what people are (  _  ) with-- that decides what they will be like? (  _  ) is it nurture --what(  _  ) to people when they are born --that decides what they will be like? Scientists have been studying twins to (  _  ) if they can find the answer, because twins start out with the (  _  ) DNA. Sometimes twins don't live together at birth and grow up in different (  _  ) and different places-- so the nature is the same for both, but the nurture is different. When scientists (  _  ) these twins in their later life, they some times find some surprising (  _  ). Jim Springer and Jim Lewis were adopted by two different families at birth. They first met each other again thirty-nine years (  _  ) and discovered they had a lot in (  _  ). Both had been (  _  ) twice. Their first wives were both named Linda and their second wives were both named Betty! Each twin had a son -- one called his son James Alan and the (  _  ) called his son James Alan, too. Their children each had a dog called "Toy". They even arrived at their first (  _  ) in the same color of car. So far twin (  _  ) seem to show that both nature and nurture are important. What we have from birth, and how and where we live help to build (  _  ) we are.
